results.title: Let's talk cricket
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Alice Jackson Walsh
results.brief_description: Alice, a Gungarri Elder from Echuca, is the former president of the Campapse Cricket Association and Warma Indigenous Cricket Club. In this warm story she reminisces about her lifelong love affair with one of our national pastimes - and reveals its social importance and grass roots support by Australians.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Alice Jackson Walsh

results.title: Gungarri woman
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Linda Wordie
results.brief_description: Linda is a Gungarri woman, and she has breast cancer. With this diagnosis you see life differently, butterflies, the moon and big cups of tea that become part of life’s healing.
results.description: Linda is a Gungarri woman, and she has breast cancer. With this diagnosis you see life differently, butterflies, the moon and big cups of tea that become part of life’s healing.

results.title: Days of Echuca
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Barbara Day
results.brief_description: Barbara courageously and openly speaks of the hardships she has endured in her life and how she has managed to recover from the tragedies of her life because she draws support from her spirituality, her family and her community. This story was produced as part of a project called Voices from the Riverlands, in partnership with the Njernda Aboriginal Corporation.

results.title: Western stories: expressions for the future. [Vol. 1]
results.brief_description:
Western Stories: Expressions for the Future is an inspirational collection of works from young people who, through their association with the Western Chances program, have been given the opportunity to tell their stories and build their own bridge to the future.
Western Chances was established to ensure that financial hardship does not prevent a young person in Melbourne’s West from achieving their maximum potential in life.

results.title: The Sacrifice
results.brief_description: A narrative of courage, family and a life saved. Dragush’s father was dying of kidney failure. His father’s sister, Lina, travelled half way across the world to Australia from Albania, leaving her home and family behind, so that she could help save her brother’s life by donating one of her own kidneys. This story is a dedication to Aunty Lina and the importance of family.

group.title: Western stories: expressions for the future. [Vol. 1]

results.title: La partria o la tumba
results.brief_description: Socialist parents, rebellious children - it runs in the blood. Esteban’s parents originally came from Uruguay but were forced to flee to Australia in 1974 from the ruling military regime. His father, aged 32, and mother, aged 21, eventually settled in Melbourne raising four children and establishing the first South American bakery, in Yarraville. In this story, Esteban talks of his family’s experiences and his deep respect for his wonderful rebellious parents.

group.title: Western stories: expressions for the future. [Vol. 1]

results.title: Heart of Otara
results.brief_description: Otara has the reputation as one of the most dangerous places in New Zealand. But for Sami, who now lives in Australia, Otara will always remain in his heart as home, as the land of his father and his family. Proud of his color and proud of his culture, Sami talks of his memories as a child, the good times and the bad including the tragic circumstances which eventually led to a new start and a new beginning in Australia. Music composed by Sami Laga.

group.title: Western stories: expressions for the future. [Vol. 1]

results.title: Ablutions
results.brief_description: Ablutions is an interactive journey where the user controls the fate of a character in a world that consumes technology. Through exploring the narrative the user partakes in the experience of cleansing the self from everyday technology and its commodities; questioning the nature of our identity. By doing this, freedom is redefined. Once cleansed, the character recovers the lost items, discovering their meaning and importance.

details.label: Subject categories
display_values: Advertising, Film, Journalism, Mass Media & TV → Interactive media

results.title: Fly
results.brief_description:
Winner of the Digital Pictures Award for best short dance film/video
was ‘Fly’ (2002) by New Zealand choreographer/director Shona
McCullough. Shona’s film, with performances from Richard Cesan and
John Callan, is a poignant story, told in dance/sign language, about
a 15 year old boy who wants to escape and 54 year old man who must
learn to let go.
